snippet: Shaukat Qadir, a retired Pakistan Army brigadier, is piecing together a decade-long parlor game among spies, soldiers and journalists, all guessing the whereabouts of the world’s most-wanted fugitive.
abstract: Shaukat Qadir, a retired Pakistan Army brigadier, has been conducting a quixotic investigation into the whereabouts of Osama bin Laden; it began as a personal attempt to truth-check the competing accounts of Bin Laden’s last years in Pakistan, but his work has already come under scrutiny and criticism, mostly on the grounds that his heavy reliance on Pakistani military and intelligence sources leaves him open to official manipulation.

byline.contributor: Salman Masood contributed reporting from Islamabad, Pakistan, and Eric Schmitt from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Shaukat Qadir, a retired Pakistan Army brigadier, is piecing together a decade-long parlor game among spies, soldiers and journalists, all guessing the whereabouts of the world’s most-wanted fugitive.

headline.seo: Quest to Clarify Bin Laden’s Last Days Yields Vexing Accounts
headline.main: A Personal Quest to Clarify Bin Laden’s Last Days Yields Vexing Accounts
headline.print_headline: A Personal Quest to Clarify Bin Laden’s Last Days Yields Vexing Accounts
